John Hawksworth, chief economist at PwC, comments on the latest UK GDP data: ​

jaws any thing in CCC please ?
BE11:15am

He sure does!

BE11:15am

"The slowdown in GDP growth to just 0.1% in the first quarter was slightly greater than we had expected, with underlying growth in the services sector decelerating in addition to the negative effects of the snow on construction and retail sales. These figures will give further ammunition to those on the MPC wanting to keeping interest rates on hold at their meeting in May.

"These are only preliminary figures and are based largely on estimates rather than actual data for March, when the snow was at its worst. So there could be larger than usual revisions as more information becomes available. Also, much of the weakness in GDP growth was due to a sharp fall in construction output. This is always volatile and has been particularly badly affected, not just by the snow but by the generally cold weather through the winter months.

"Nonetheless, there has been an underlying decline in momentum on consumer spending over the past year, which has outweighed relatively stronger performance by more export-oriented sectors such as manufacturing and business services that have benefitted from the strength of the global economy. Continuing uncertainty around Brexit has also dampened business investment, particularly in areas like commercial property.

"The UK remains firmly in the slow lane of global growth and these figures indicate a further loss of momentum in early 2018."

wayneJ GDP - questions are (1) is there any impact of Brexit (2) slow down in FDI (3) Property
wayneJ Also (4) autos / manufacturing
wayneJ [I really want Dr Liam Fox and Michael Gove to set up a Ministry of Truth]
11:16 am
BE11:16am

So, yeah, sharper slowdown than expected. But the snow effect was "generally small" and only really visible in the construction and retail sectors.

BE11:16am

Construction downl 3.3% q-o-q

But that's diddly squat really. About 0.03 of a percentage point off of the GDP growth total, with the counterbalance of utility costs as everyone cranks up the central heating.

wayneJ Does raise issues on valuation of shopping mall owners such as Hammerson - is it just an Amazonian effect + snow?

Does this change anything? ..... Maybe. Here's HSBC.

BE11:18am

The Bank of England was expecting a print of 0.3% q-o-q including a 0.1pp drag from snow (so underlying growth of 0.4%), according to the minutes of the MPC's 21 March meeting. In underlying growth terms then, today's number implies a considerable disappointment relative to BoE expectations.

wayneJ Surely there ought to be a breakdown of salt consumption or something to give us a benchmark on how big the snow effect really is?
Istrain Is now the time to reference Miles Johnson's piece in todays paper pointing out the weak correlation of economic data and market returns?
11:18 am
BE11:18am

Bear in mind that at this stage, a lot of the snow impact is (educated) guesswork on the part of the statisticians. The preliminary GDP estimate is typically based on just 40% of the data that will ultimately become available. In this release, very little hard data will have been available for March. So the statisticians will have had to forecast the impact based on early responses, other surveys (eg the PMIs) and past experiences of adverse weather.
4 This means today's number could be subject to larger than normal future revisions. This was certainly the case for Q4 2010, which included heavy snow. The initial release was -0.5% q-o-q. Today it is estimated at +0.1%.

Mouselet Good morning capitalists
Pharma @WayneJ, it will be nothing to do with how bad the snow was, but rather how many schools were shut. The two do not seem to be in any way correlated.
FATDAZ Sorry to be a kill joy but BRC Retail sales data showed rising sales during the bad weather on both Food and Non food Items
Paper Chase Hullo. Sorry I'm late. Was trying to get into my TSB account. True story.

So .......... the apparent lack of snow impact means it's significant for BOE purposes, but also makes the data hard to pin down as clear.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

The ONS states that construction and retail were the areas where snow disruption was most evident. Stripping out these sectors, we calculate growth would have been 0.2%-0.3%. This is below the BoE's expectation that underlying Q1 growth would be 0.4%. Over time, we wouldn’t be surprised to see the snow impact revised larger, implying a smaller miss in underlying growth relative to BoE expectations. But that won't become evident for a while.
The preliminary Q1 GDP print is the last piece of significant hard data before the highly uncertain May policy decision, although the MPC will get the April PMIs shortly before it meets. While these may rebound, today's data will give the MPC further cause for concern.
So alongside a fall back in consumer confidence in April (data released today showed it slipping by two points to -9) means the MPC will have yet more weak data to digest in its 10 May meeting. Following his recent comments that a 25bps rate rise in May is far from a done deal, BoE Governor Mark Carney might try and steer the MPC to waiting for the fog (or snow) to clear before raising rates again. It would also allow more time to assess the extent of the global slowdown increasingly evident in data. This provides a clear risk to our long-held view that the BoE will hike in May.

shaunrc999 Er Construction was 0.21% off GDP Bryce

And just to drive the point home, here's Davy's Conall MacCoille.

wayneJ GFK Consumer Confidence was -9 vs expected -7
BE11:22am

Markets had priced in a May rate hike to 0.75% as a forgone conclusion following the Bank of England’s surprisingly hawkish February Inflation Report. However, recent comments from Governor Mark Carney, pointing to other meetings and highlighting softer data, have muddied the waters. Overnight Index Swaps (OIS) are now pricing in just a 57% probability of a hike in May and only a 40% probability of two hikes by end-2018. Of course, a weak GDP reading this morning could further depress rate expectations.

BE11:32am

Overall, 1Q18 constant currency revenue growth at a group level was 21%, although this included a large (low margin) software licence deal. Even excluding this £34m deal, underlying growth was very strong at 17%. Behind the headlines, this growth is driven by Supply Chain which grew 25% (excluding the one-off deal), balanced across the UK (+37%) and Germany (+25%). Supply Chain in France was -1%.

wayneJ Not sure that Travis Perkins statement reads particularly confidently
FATDAZ @Pharma I thought build it broken was the software mantra
BE11:33am

Services remains muted: Management has been more cautious on Services and this is reflected in 1Q18 results; with growth at 0%. This includes robust demand for Professional Services, but more difficult Managed Services. In Germany, total Services growth was 7% but, in the UK, Services declined 7% due to the non-recurrence of sizeable contracts last year and the ramp down of a large contract.

Fox So interest rate rise less likely now next month?
BE11:33am

Following the updated guidance that management now expects profits growth this year, we upgrade our FY18 and FY19 EPS by 2%. We value Computacenter on a 6% FY19 FCF yield, broadly in line with the rest of the sector and take account of the net cash position. This justifies a revised TP of 1400p and supports our Outperform rating. The risk to our target price is a reversal of fortunes in France, which has seen a period of mixed trading.

RBS has made considerable progress in terms of addressing the challenges of its past, but for the investment case, key uncertainties remain. Today’s Q1 IMS offers some encouragement, with u/l PBT of £1.5bn some £0.2bn (18%) ahead of company-compiled consensus. tNAV per share rose 3p QoQ to 297p (consensus 294p) and CET1 capital rose 0.5% QoQ to 16.4% (consensus 16.3%). However, we still expect Q2 2018e tNAV to mark the bottom. HOLD.

BE11:41am

Underlying revenues of £3.3bn are up 3% YoY and represent a £0.1bn (4%) beat vs consensus (£3.2bn). Underlying costs of £1.8bn are down 2% YoY, a £27m (2%) miss vs consensus. The impairment charge of only £0.1bn is £32m (70%) above Q1 2017, but a £0.1bn (60%) beat vs consensus. U/L PBT of £1.5bn is up £0.1bn (8%) YoY and a £0.2bn (18%) beat vs consensus.

BE11:41am

After a (low) restructuring charge of £0.2bn and with minimal other exceptional items, Profit Attributable is £0.8bn, a £0.5bn (150%) beat vs consensus.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

You following all this?

BE11:41am

tNAV per shares rises 3p QoQ to 297p, (consensus 294p; INVe 298p). However, the 17 April pension settlement is expected to have a 12p adverse impact upon recognition in Q2, and the last material RBMS provision may yet be taken then too. Our current Q2 2018e tNAV forecast is 267p.

BE11:41am

CET1 capital improved by 0.5% QoQ to 16.4%, though the pension settlement will lead to a 0.8% deduction in Q2 2018 in relation to the £2bn payment to be made in H2 2018. (This does not reflect further anticipated contributions of up to £1.5bn through 2020-2022).

The only deal I found that ever collapsed in this stage was Zurich for RSA and that was the bidder walking, which Takeda seems extremely unlikely to do at this point. Just wondering if you remember any? Thanks

FATDAZ @Wayne J thanks
BE11:45am

Overall tone was constructive on their performance but they recognise there are challenges ahead on mortgages and an overhang while the DOJ is resolved. 3 key points to highlight: 1) Mortgage market remains a key focus for them despite the slower Q1 - it is still a very attractive ROE business and whilst margins are under pressure (BB greater than FB by 80bps) they are seeing signs of pricing movements upwards from peers, though things remain very competitive. 2) Impairments – they weren’t
involved in the high profile cases this quarter. However they are 25-30% of the market so they will see a pick up in impairments and still flagging the 35-40bps through the cycle level. 3) Capital build puts them one step away from returns - they are in dialogue with the DOJ but appreciate that this is somewhat of a moving target. Clearly if DOJ takes longer to resolve then it could be that they approach the PRA to start nominal dividend payments ahead of any outsized returns beyond a resolution - for every £1bn extra in fines it is 35bps in CET1. We have c.£5bn in DOJ with c. 300bps in excess capital.

Flaneur @hornblower - I doubt it. He didnt get the memo - wars arent meant to be won; they're meant to be continuous.

I get the spread can be wider than normal (eventuality of Takeda shareholder vote, financing, still needs a 2.7 announcement etc), but what I am seeing is Shire that traded at 39 GBP just in December and probably having 10-12% downside on a break now, given arbs have not really legged in. Deal spread of 23%, so trades at 33% probability (give or take). If you look at the holders, the US ADRs which are half the trading are held by US instos, I see only very limity UK holders in the UK listing. So I do not think many people have issues with a Takeda US listing. Especially as this premium lets them cash out. Shire shareholders on the whole should be very happy here.

Exhibit 21 above highlights the potential earnings accretion (pre-synergies) that Klepierre’s acquisition of HMSO could provide. Based on our FY18 EPS estimates, Klepierre’s forward earnings yield is 7.3% and HMSO’s is 5.3%. Assigning a 1.5% cost of debt, the 50% shares, 50% cash acquisition which creates 86bps of earnings accretion on Klepierre’s first indicative offer (615p) and 70bps on the increase 635p offer. The deal would be earnings accretive up to an offer price of 725p. A 725p offer would take LTV up to 48.1% versus 47.1% on the 635p offer however gearing levels this late in the cycle would warrant further disposals into weak UK markets as we would expect Klepierre to divest much of HMSO’s retail park portfolio and lower quality shopping centres as well some of its own secondary assets offsetting much of the synergies that could be created.
